previous_statement: For all valued fields k, all normed k-spaces E,F, and all e in E, f in F: if e⊗f = v₁⊗w₁ + v₂⊗w₂ + v₃⊗(αw₁+βw₂) is a 3-term dependent representation in E⊗F with {w₁,w₂} a basis, then ‖v₁‖‖w₁‖ + ‖v₂‖‖w₂‖ + ‖v₃‖‖αw₁+βw₂‖ ≥ ‖e‖‖f‖. Equivalently: the Cross Property π(e⊗f) = ‖e‖‖f‖ holds for 3-term representations over the pathological norm on Cₚ².
new_statement: For all valued fields k, all normed k-spaces E,F, and all e in E, f in F: if e⊗f = v₁⊗w₁ + v₂⊗w₂ + v₃⊗(αw₁+βw₂) is a 3-term dependent representation in E⊗F with {w₁,w₂} a basis, then ‖v₁‖‖w₁‖ + ‖v₂‖‖w₂‖ + ‖v₃‖‖αw₁+βw₂‖ ≥ ‖e‖‖f‖. A key test case: the Cross Property π(e⊗f) = ‖e‖‖f‖ for 3-term representations over (Cₚ², N) with the pathological norm N. This test case is a necessary condition (if CP fails over some valued field, reduction to k² with some norm N_E on E and N_F on F gives a counterexample; testing specific norms on Cₚ² can detect such failures) but is not known to be equivalent to the universal statement without further argument showing (i) it suffices to test N_E = N_F, (ii) the pathological norm is extremal among non-archimedean norms on k², and (iii) Cₚ is universal among valued fields for this purpose.
